title: Natural Ways to Get Rid of Static Cling

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Ever since moving up north, static cling has become the bane of my existence. Of course before switching to all-natural products we used dryer sheets, so static in the laundry was never really an issue. But now that I know the dangers of dryer sheets (more on that below) I’ve had to resort to more natural ways to get rid of static cling.

Some have worked well, others not so much. But there’s also one product that has really been doing the job for me, and doing it pretty well!

What’s wrong with dryer sheets?

I won’t go into the individual ingredients and their effects on the nervous system and the environment, as there are plenty of other sources that do a great job of that (like here and here), but I will point you to this study that analyzed the volatile organic compounds (VOCs) given off by various scented household and bath products, including dryer sheets.

These compounds are, at the very least, toxic and hazardous to our health, and at the very worst, they are carcinogenic air pollutants with no safe exposure level.

No good all around.

Now I know why I have such a hard time walking past the cleaning aisle at the grocery store and why I avoid it like the plague.

What are some natural ways to get rid of static cling?

Do we really need dryer sheets and fabric softeners to do our laundry? For me the answer has been a resounding NO for the past several years, but it’s definitely been a long journey to get to a comfortable and content place with my laundry routine.

Here are some of the things I’ve tried, as well as some other ideas I’ve seen floating around online:

  1. Vinegar in the rinse cycle: I add about 1/4 up of vinegar to my washer’s rinse cycle to soften and freshen laundry. It works great to reduce static on loads that are mostly cotton (towels, sheets, etc.), but it’s not enough for things like fleece blankets and polyester clothing.
  2. Dryer balls: Made of felted wool, these balls are put into the dryer along with your laundry and help speed up drying time as well as reducing static. I use this brand, but you can also try making them at home.
  3. Line drying: Most of the time static cling is caused by over-drying your laundry, so line drying either outside or on an indoor drying rack will help reduce static, or eliminate it altogether. You might even try just line drying your synthetic fabrics, like polyester, nylon, etc. since those are usually the main culprits.
  4. Shake it out: If you do use the dryer, make sure to shake out your clothes right when you take them out of the dryer. This helps keep the static from setting in, and also reduces wrinkles.
  5. Aluminum foil: I haven’t tried this because I’m not sure how natural it is, but it seems to work for a lot of people. Just make a couple of plum-sized balls out of aluminum foil, and toss them into the dryer with your laundry to help eliminate static cling.

What about after the laundry?

The above methods all work in and around the laundry routine, but what about after the laundry? What can be done to get rid of static cling say, once your clothes are already on your body? Or after that fleece blanket is already covering you in your in bed? 

  • Water or lotion: Rub some water or lotion on your hands, and then lightly run your hands on your clothes, hair, or bedding for a quick fix.
  • Metal hanger trick: I haven’t personally tried this, but you take a metal hanger and run it between your body and your clothes to break the electric charge.
  • Static sprays: There are commercial sprays on the market, but like the dryer sheets, they just do more harm than good. 

Is there a natural static spray that actually works?

Yes, there is! It’s called Static Schmatic, and it’s my new go-to spray for clothes, hair, and even the kids. It’s 100% natural and contains only 5 ingredients – no harmful chemicals, no artificial fragrances or scents, and no buildup or residue left behind. It’s safe for people, pets, and the environment.

I’ve been using it now for just about a month, and this stuff has truly been a sanity saver. I keep a bottle in the laundry room, and another in my purse for quick touch-ups on the go. It works every. single. time. 

Fleece blankets causing sparks in the night? Static Schmatic to the rescue.

Kids’ hair got them sporting an Einstein ‘do? Static Schmatic, baby.

Hubby’s pants sticking to his socks and holding on for dear life? You guessed it, Static Schmatic.

Seriously, just a couple of quick sprays, and I’m done.

They have 4 different formulas: clothes, hair, kids, and pets. The kids one smells of sweet vanilla, so I’ve found myself randomly taking whiffs of their hair because it just smells so darn good. 🙂

Before & After

The best part? Static Schmatic was created by two moms (a mother-daughter team) and is made in the USA. I’m beyond impressed with this product – it’s natural, eco-friendly, and it gets the job done!

Check out Static Schmatic on Facebook and Instagram. And if you’d like to try their product, they’re offering a special offer just for Nature’s Nurture readers – use the code Natures10 at checkout to receive 10% off your order until June 30, 2015!

What are your natural ways to get rid of static cling? What other ideas have you tried?

title: How to Use Leftover Almond Pulp (from almond milk)

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Are you making homemade almond milk yet? If not, you totally should be! And if you are, well you’ve probably got a freezer full of leftover almond pulp. Or – gasp! – you’re just dumping it in the trash or the compost. Either way, if you’re like me, you’ve been scrambling around looking for new ways to use all that leftover almond pulp!

In my almond milk post, I shared how to dry the pulp and turn it into almond meal to use in recipes that call for almond flour, or to replace some of the wheat flour in your muffin, cookie, or bread recipes. But if you don’t feel like drying each and every batch of almond pulp, you can always just dump the pulp in a freezer bag or jar and freeze it until you need it.

I’ve made this almond pulp freezer fudge many times, and it’s a huge hit around here. But at just 1/2 cup of almond pulp per batch, there’s no way I can use it up quickly enough.

So I went on a search to find all the wonderful ways to use leftover almond pulp, and I found a whole world of ideas!

Ways to Use Leftover Almond Pulp

  • Add it to pancakes and waffles – just replace some of the flour in your recipe with almond pulp. You might have to experiment to get the batter just right.
  • Add it to smoothies – throw a handful of almond pulp into your green smoothie for a tasty protein boost!
  • Use as a binder for meatloaf, meatballs, or veggie burgers – replace some or all of the soaked bread crumbs in your recipe with some almond pulp. 
  • Make these vegan, paleo crackers – these come together so quickly and easily with some oil, salt, and fresh herbs. 
  • Make some raw pizza crust – the only ingredient you may need to buy for this recipe is ground flax seed, so if you’ve already got that then you can make this tonight!
  • Make these no-bake peanut butter cookie dough balls – did someone just say NO BAKE? Yes!! These are also vegan and gluten free if you use gluten-free oats like these.
  • Make these raw cacao coconut balls – few things go together as well as chocolate and coconut, and these balls are no exception. I think I’m making these this week!
  • Make the crusts for these summer berry tarts – just the nut pulp and some dates – that’s it!
  • Whip up this hearty almond spread to serve with crackers – This one sounds very interesting. Garlic, sun-dried tomatoes, herbs, olive oil, and nutritional yeast come together with the almond pulp to make a smooth pate-like spread.
  • Make these delectable gluten-free, vegan chocolate chip bars – A healthier, tastier version of the store-bought bars without all the preservatives and artificial ingredients. You’ll need some ground flax seed, gluten-free oats, and dairy-free chocolate chips to make these vegan and gluten free.
  • Make these almond pulp bars – I’ll bet you’ve already got everything you need in your pantry to make these quick, simple healthy bars. I’m starting a batch today!

More ways to use leftover almond pulp…

Almond Pulp Breakfast Bars | Pale Yellow
Baked Almond Pulp Brownies | The Bojon Gourmet
Raw Almond Pulp Hummus | Eating Vibrantly
Raw Pumpkin Bread | Small Footprint Family
Almond Pulp Granola | +Chloe
Raw Banana Breakfast Bites | Zakka Sweet Design

What fun ways have you used your leftover almond pulp after making almond milk? I’m always looking for new ideas!

title: Keeping Families Together with Haiti Babi Blankets {Review}

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
I’m a huge fan of social enterprises, so when I see one that catches my eye, I just want to sing about it from the rooftops! That’s why I want to tell you all about Haiti Babi, a company that helps empower Haitian mothers by giving them job opportunities making baby blankets and hats.

Haiti Babi provides a fair living wage to Haitian mothers so they can support their families and end the cycle of poverty. But that’s not what caught my attention about this wonderful company. What really affected me about this story is the fact that many of the children in Haiti’s orphanages are actually put there by their own parents because they simply can’t provide for them. So the orphanage is the only solution for giving their children the basic necessities of life.

Katlin Jackson started Haiti Babi after an eye-opening and life-changing volunteer trip to Haiti. After seeing firsthand the effects of poverty on Haitian children and how it’s literally tearing families apart, she decided to create a sustainable solution for this common problem. Instead of giving them a hand out, she sought to give them a hand up.

And Haiti Babi was born. A company whose sole purpose is to keep children out of orphanages and with their parents. Soon, their operation was set up, moms were hired, and beautiful handmade baby blankets were being crocheted with love and dignity.

With compensation and benefits, a Haiti Babi mom earns more than two times the minimum wage. This income allows her to cover the basic needs of her family and save more than half of her income for the future.  To help make these paychecks even more of an empowerment tool, we are currently working on teaching our moms in Haiti the basics about budgeting and handling their money. -Haiti Babi

And they really are beautiful! And super soft and comfy. Made from 100% cotton, these plush blankets not only look and feel great; they also serve as a wonderful reminder of the work that went into making them and the families they are supporting.

There’s something truly special about a handmade gift; but a handmade gift that’s also helping to keep families together? Now that’s priceless. 🙂

You can browse their selection of blankets and hats at their website. The blankets retail for $78 and the hats for $25. They also sell them together as gift sets. You can also keep up with them on Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, and Instagram.

title: 10 Easy Ways to Make a Difference on Earth Day (and Everyday!)

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Happy Earth Day, everyone!  

The day we celebrate and honor our one and only home – our beautiful planet Earth. While we’re all thinking of ways to show our love for the earth, this year I’m focusing on the little things we all can do everyday to go green and some easy ways to make a difference on Earth Day.

Ways to Make a Difference on Earth Day

  1. Wash clothes in cold water – I started doing this about a year ago, and I’ve never looked back! The only laundry I wash in hot water is our towels and anything that needs a good sanitizing cycle. Other than that, all of our clothes are washed in tap cold water, which saves money and energy.
  2. Line dry your laundry – I’m still struggling with this one, but I’m trying to dry more of our laundry on a drying rack to further help cut our electric bill. I also want to put up a line in our backyard to line dry our clothes now that the weather is warming up again.
  3. Turn off the tap while brushing your teeth – When I was younger, I always left the tap running while brushing my teeth. I don’t know why, but looking back of course I realize just how stupid that was. Just turn off the tap; it’s wasted water and money down the drain.
  4. Shop at thrift stores and garage sales – Not only can you find awesome deals on discontinued and vintage items, shopping at thrift stores and garage sales helps keep unwanted items out of the landfill and into a new home. Thrifting is one of my favorite pastimes; I’ve come across some really great finds over the years!
  5. Walk, bike, carpool – Just one day a week, try to leave the car at home and take a walk instead. Or better yet, ride your bike down to that corner store, and get some exercise in while you’re at it! And of course, the age old tradition of carpooling with a coworker or classmate never goes out of style. 🙂
  6. Use reusable shopping bags – More and more cities are instituting a plastic bag ban; my city of Toronto has done the same, but they still sell bags at 5 cents each if you need them, which I think is kind of silly. But it’s still a step in the right direction, I suppose. Get yourself a few sturdy reusable shopping bags (they’re even available right at your grocery store!) to do your weekly shopping, and keep those pesky plastic bags out of the landfill.
  7. Reduce your trash – Decluttering is wonderful, but if you’re just dumping everything in the trash, you’re probably just creating more problems. Instead, try to find a new home or new uses for your unwanted items. Either donate them to charity or thrift stores, try to repurpose them into new things, or recycle them. Anything is better than just putting it on the curb to be dropped off at the landfill.
  8. Use reusable water bottles – We’ve been using and loving our glass and stainless steel water bottles for us and the kids for about 5 years now. In the very rare occurrence that I need to drink from a plastic bottle, I can literally taste the plastic in my water! Blechh… Glass or stainless steel are your best options to not only reduce your waste, but also reduce your consumption of fossil fuels that are used to manufacture and transport all those bottles. Not to mention all of the chemicals that leach into the water, like BPA, etc.
  9. Take shorter showers – This is by far the hardest one for me to stick to. I love me a hot a shower! And since becoming a mother, those long hot showers are few and far between. 😉 So I’ll admit, when I get the chance to indulge, I still do. But for the most part, my showers tend to be fairly quick.
  10. Raise/Lower the thermostat – Turn your thermostat a few degrees up in the summer and a few degrees down in the winter. Just a few degrees will make all the difference in your cooling and heating costs and energy consumption.

Alright, your turn! What are some easy ways that you try to make a difference on Earth Day and everyday? Please share in the comments!

title: Overcoming “Natural Living Fatigue” – My Natural Living Confession

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
I have a confession to make. A natural living confession. Something I really need to get off my chest. Because in this world of natural, organic, eco-friendly living, it’s easy to get lost in an “all or nothing” mindset. So I’m here to set the record straight.

I’m not 100% natural.

Nope, not even close. I’m guessing you’re not either. And you know what? It’s OK! I’m not sure anyone can truly say they live a 100% natural lifestyle, and there’s absolutely nothing wrong with that. 

We live in a time when we’re constantly bombarded with product after product, advertisement after advertisement, post after post about what we’re doing wrong in our daily lives. About how our food is going to kill us. How our beauty products will give us cancer. How our cleaning supplies will leave us with chronic health conditions. 

It can be so overwhelming!

One of my readers actually emailed me recently asking how I deal with what she called “natural living fatigue.” I’d already been working on this post for a few days when she emailed me, and I was so thankful because she basically gave me the title for this post. So, thanks Maureen! 🙂

Here’s what I had to say to Maureen:

I’m totally with you, especially now after having 3 kids all under the age of 4. Sometimes I just want to give in and buy that frozen pizza, or get the store bought dish soap, or use the not so natural skin cream on my son’s eczema just because it’s quicker and more convenient. And you know what, sometimes I just do –  for the sake of my sanity! I think the fatigue comes from the constant feeling of guilt, but if we remove the guilt and just allow ourselves to not be so. darn. perfect. every once in a while, maybe – just maybe! – that feeling of fatigue won’t be so overwhelming.

Overcoming Natural Living Fatigue

I’m realizing that the important thing is to prioritize our values when it comes to natural living. Is it just safe, natural products that we’re after? What about saving money? Sustainability? Caring for the earth? And where does convenience come into play here?

In all actuality, it’s a combination of all of these (and more), but for each individual person and in each individual area of his or her life, some of these things take higher priority than others. The trick is to decide which of these are of utmost importance (the ones you won’t budge on) and to find your balance within all of the rest (the ones for which you’ll allow yourself some wiggle room).

So what does that look like?

Well for me, it means that even though I have a recipe for homemade dish soap, I still have a backup bottle of the store bought natural dish soap. You know, for those times that the bottle of homemade soap is empty and I just can’t be bothered to mix up a new batch because 2 of my kids are fighting, the other one is crying, and I really need to wash those bowls to make them some oatmeal in the morning, so they can sit and eat.  

So you know what? I open up my cabinet, pull out my backup bottle of dish soap, and wash those bowls. No guilt. Oatmeal is made. Kids are quiet. All is well in the world again. 🙂

Which brings me to another confession…

I use a microwave. I know I shouldn’t. I know that there are other, healthier ways to warm up or reheat our food, but sometimes (like in my oatmeal story, for example) choosing between a couple of minutes in the microwave and 15 minutes standing in front of the stove is just a no-brainer. And how am I supposed to reheat that bowl of spaghetti? The toaster oven? The stove? I seriously have no idea…

Nope, sorry, it’s going in the microwave, my friend.

Oh, and while we’re on the topic of food, here’s another one for you. While we don’t eat out that much (maybe a couple times a month), and I do strive to cook most of our meals from scratch, sometimes we opt for ready-made foods like frozen pizzas, ready-made spaghetti sauce, and organic canned beans. 

Seriously, thank God for Costco and their wonderful selection of natural and organic products! 🙂

Yes, I know how to make these things from scratch, but during this season of my life, convenience is definitely taking a front seat these days.

We still read labels; we still go for organic when we can afford it and when it’s available; we still try our hardest to make sure that our meals and snacks are not laden with artificial colors and flavors, massive amounts of sugar or salt, or hydrogenated oils and trans fats.

Because these things are still important to us.

And other things are important for our family as well, like saving money, sustainability, and protecting our family from unnecessary harsh chemicals.

We still make our homemade deodorant because it’s the only thing that works for us; we still use our homemade laundry detergent because it’s so darn cheap to make; and we never buy commercial cleaning products because my homemade floor cleaner works great for nearly every surface in the house.

And that’s my point here. 

Each of us has our own set of priorities when it comes to our natural living journey. And these priorities are always changing and evolving with our seasons of life. 

Wha’t important for me today may not be so tomorrow, and where I’m slacking today may take the highest priority for me next year. 

And that’s ok. 

Because that’s life. It’s crazy and messy and constantly changing. It’s here today and gone tomorrow. 

It’s also very short, in the grand scheme of things. Too short to be obsessing about every little thing in our lives. And definitely too short to be feeling guilty about what we feed our families or whether or not we make all of our bath products at home.

The truth is, we’re all doing the very best we can with what we have. And that’s what’s really important here.

So let’s make a promise to each other, right here, right now. Let’s drop the guilt, OK? It’s unhealthy and counterproductive. 

Instead, let’s cut ourselves some slack, acknowledge how far we’ve come, be grateful for what we have, and just keep on keepin’ on…

Do you have a natural living confession? What are your tips for overcoming that guilty feeling? Which areas in your life are most important? Which ones take less priority? Please share your story in the comments!

title: Taking a Break…

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
It’s been a long time coming, but I’ve decided to take a much needed, long overdue break from blogging for a bit. This definitely was not an easy decision to make, but I’m positive it’s the right decision. 

This blog is my baby. It’s been around for as long as (and even longer than!) my first born, Yusuf. He was the very reason I ever started this blog. Because I wanted to do better by him – before I’d ever met him.

And now that my boy is 3.5 years old, we’re entering a new phase in his life. The preschool stage. 

We’ve been “homeschooling” from the very beginning and will continue to do so, but I’m going to need to carve out more time for this. And, of course, that time has to come from somewhere…

 We’ve also been blessed with two girls as well. Maryam was born in August 2013, and Bayan was born this past September 2014.

Yep, they’re exactly 13 months apart!

So basically, we’ve got all kinds of crazy going on at our house. 😉

And after a long time of thinking and reflecting, I know it’s best if I take a step back from blogging for a bit. Just to recharge, refresh, and reassess.

Because let’s face it. I’ve been struggling to keep up with the blog and still manage all of my personal and home responsibilities. There’s only so much one can do in a day or a week, and I’ve stretched myself way too thin. 

So now the blog is starting to feel more like a chore and not so much the passionate work that it was meant to be. That it used to be. Before life got all crazy with the kids. Before we were blessed as a “party of five.”

And now that the dust seems to be settling after the whirlwind that was the last few years, I really need to just take a step back from everything and just figure out this new life of ours. Figure out the intricacies of life as a party of five. And how each of us fits into the big picture. 

I’m taking a break because I know that if I don’t, I’ll regret it later.

I’m taking a break because everyone reaches a point in his or her life that’s similar to this. But not everyone actually takes the break. 

I’m taking the break…

What will I do?

It’s no coincidence that this decision is coming right at the start of 2015. I’ve been thinking about this for a while, and it just seems like the perfect time to start.

So, aside from spending more time working on home projects, I have a few things that I’ll be working on for the blog:

Study herbalism

I’m a lifelong learner, so I love delving into new arenas and immersing myself in knowledge. And after a long search, I’ve finally decided to go ahead and jump feet first into an area that has always intrigued me: herbalism. I want to learn all there is to know about using plants as food and medicine, so I’m signing up for the online introductory course at the Herbal Academy of New England.

Reassess and refocus

I started this blog about 4 years ago, when I was pregnant with Yusuf. Since then it has grown and evolved into something much bigger than I’d ever anticipated when I first started. For that, I am truly humbled and forever grateful. I think we’re quickly approaching a new level, and I need time to reassess the direction of Nature’s Nurture and refocus my efforts.

Freshen up

While I’m at it, I figured I’d do some housekeeping and freshen up the blog bit. So we just might have a new look when we come back after the break! 🙂

How long will we be gone?

Good question. Right now, I’m planning to be out for about 3 months. I want to return right around the shift in seasons, as we welcome Spring and all it has to offer. 

Poetic? I think so. 🙂

If you need to contact me…

Although I won’t be blogging, I’ll still be online and connected. If you have a question or need help with something, please connect with me over on Facebook, Instagram, or Twitter.

If you email me or contact me through the blog, I can’t guarantee that I’ll get back to you in a timely manner, but I promise I’ll try. 🙂

Same goes for any comments left on blog posts. I’ll be moderating/approving comments, but I won’t necessarily be able to answer questions or contribute to the discussion. 

Well, I guess that about covers it! I’m excited about this, but it’s also a bit scary and uncertain. So any helpful thoughts or prayers are always appreciated.

Thank you so much. Wishing you all a warm and cozy Winter, and I’ll see you in the Spring, God-willing. 🙂

title: My Baby Wearing Journey (Plus a giveaway for Canadians!)

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
When I became pregnant with Yusuf over 4 years ago, my mind went into overdrive with all the things I wanted to learn and do to prepare for the arrival of our first-born. (That’s actually when Nature’s Nurture officially became a blog as well!)

In addition to having a natural pregnancy and delivery, I knew I wanted to practice natural, gentle parenting – what I later came to know as attachment parenting. And one of the pillars of attachment parenting is baby wearing.

It all made perfect sense. Keeping baby close by wearing him in a carrier, especially when out and about, seemed so much easier and more practical. Not only that, but having him so close means mom is much more sensitive to his needs and able to respond to them quickly. And baby is more content because he’s constantly soothed by mom’s warmth and heartbeat.

It seemed like a win/win, so I went for it.

I initially bought one of those stretchy wraps to wear Yusuf, but once I actually tried to wrap that long piece of fabric around myself, I knew it just wasn’t right for me. It was just too much fabric, too much wrapping, too much time… Don’t get me wrong, some mamas love their wraps and they work for them (which is awesome – rock on, mama!), but for me personally, it was more of a hassle than I cared to deal with.

One day at one of my breastfeeding mama meetings, my friend, Shelly, told me about the Baby K’Tan – a wrap style carrier without all the fabric and wrapping and time… She even let me try hers on, and from that moment I fell in love with the Baby K’Tan, went home, and ordered one right away! So I’ve been a fan of Baby K’Tan for several years now and have used their carriers for all three of my kids, including our newest little, Bayan. 🙂

I usually use the Baby K’Tan for the first 4 months or so, then I switch to a soft-structured carrier once the Baby K’Tan just isn’t giving me the support that I need. According to the folks at Baby K’Tan, their carriers would work for up to a 35 lb. toddler, but I usually move on once our babies reach the 15-20 pound mark. 

I recently got the chance to try the Baby K’Tan Breeze, which is made of 50% cotton and 50% mesh to help reduce heat and moisture. It provides a cooler, more breathable, and more comfortable carrier for warmer weather and outdoor use. 

The Baby K’Tan is simply 2 large loops of fabric that are connected by another smaller loop of fabric – the back support band. You slip the 2 loops around your neck (like a necklace), then separate them by placing one arm in each loop, and slipping one off your shoulder. Once baby is in the carrier, you pull down on the back support band to adjust it and you’re set. 

 

It also comes with a sash, for extra safety and support, which converts into a neat little carrying case.

It’s so simple and easy to wear, and it feels so nice and snug once it’s on. I really like the Baby K’Tan Breeze and actually prefer it over the regular Baby K’Tan. I guess the mesh just makes it feel tighter and more secure.

If you’re interested in baby wearing, the Baby K’Tan is a great beginner wrap. But even if you’re a seasoned pro, it’s still a great choice for on-the-go moms (and dads too!)

title: 5 Ways to Use Soap Nuts

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
I just discovered the wonderful world of soap nuts, and I’m in love! Soap nuts are the only laundry detergent in the world that actually grows on trees. But they’re good for more than just cleaning your clothes; they’ve got all kinds of uses around the home! Today, I’m sharing the 5 best ways to use soap nuts, plus where to go to find even more uses for these nifty little berries.

What are soap nuts?

Soap nuts are not actually a nut, but a berry that grows on the Sapindus Mukorossi tree and contains a natural surfactant, called saponin, which cleans your clothes by lifting the dirt off of them. They’re also 100% natural, non-toxic, hypoallergenic, and eco-friendly, making them a great choice for use around children, pets, and those with sensitive skin.

5 Ways to Use Soap Nuts

Besides just throwing the nuts (or adding a few pumps of the liquid) into your washing machine to wash your clothes, there are actually quite a few other ways to use soap nuts:

  1. All-Purpose Cleaner – A concentrated liquid cleaner for use all over the home. 
  2. Powdered Laundry Detergent – A borax-free powder detergent that’s great for clothes and cloth diapers.
  3. Soap Nuts Shampoo – A simple shampoo that cleans and nourishes hair, and an herbal shampoo with marshmallow root, herbs, aloe vera gel, and more.
  4. Soap Nuts In the Dishwasher – Super simple and frugal way to wash your dishes!
  5. Homemade Soap Nuts Liquid – If you’re ready to venture into DIY, you can try making the soap nuts liquid right at home.

But that’s not all; there’s so much more! Check out the links below for even more ways to use soap nuts, as well as some helpful tips and advice to get the most use out of them. 

The Mother of All Soap Nuts Recipes from Crunchy Betty – Apparently, soap nuts can be used in 4 different forms: whole berry, liquid, paste, and powder. This post has even more ways to use soap nuts, with everything from glass cleaner and bug spray, to shaving cream and dandruff treatment.

How to Tell If Soap Nuts Still Have Cleaning Power from Kitchen Stewardship – The directions on soap nuts usually say that the nuts are ready to toss once they’ve turned a light brown/gray color and become very soft, thin, and mushy. As helpful as those instructions are, there’s a much better way to test your soap nuts’ cleaning power.

5 Uses for Soap Nuts from Surviving the Stores – There’s a toothpaste recipe in here!

Where to Buy Soap Nuts

I’ve personally tried soap nuts from both Green Virgin Products and Mountain Rose Herbs, and I love them both. You can read my review of Green Virgin Products’ soap nuts here and purchase them either from their website or on Amazon. Mountain Rose Herbs’ soap nuts can be purchased here.

title: The Wonderful World of Soap Nuts

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Have you heard of soap nuts before? I hadn’t until very recently, and they’re amazing! If you’re looking for another natural option for cleaning your clothes (and so much more!), you’ve got to check out today’s post on the wonderful world soap nuts.

When I first heard about soap nuts, I actually couldn’t believe it. I mean really? There’s a tree out there that grows nuts that you can use for cleaning? No way.

Yes way!

What are soap nuts?

Soap nuts are not actually nuts; they’re dried berry shells that just look like nuts (so they’re 100% safe for those with nut allergies!). They contain a natural surfactant, called saponin, which basically helps to clean by lifting the dirt off of your clothes (or any surface). Soap nuts are the only laundry detergent in the world that grow on trees! They’re also 100% natural, non-toxic, hypoallergenic, and eco-friendly, making them a much gentler option for use around the home.

How to Use Soap Nuts for Laundry

Super easy. Just drop a few of the nuts into a cotton muslin bag, toss the bag into the bottom of the washer, add your clothes, and wash like normal. That’s it. See? Easy. Peasy.

For more ways to use soap nuts, besides on the laundry room, check out my other post on 5 Ways to Use Soap Nuts!

I had the chance to try soap nuts for the first time when Green Virgin Products contacted me a few months ago. They claim to sell the highest quality soap nuts at the lowest price, so I knew I had to give them a shot.

Green Virgin Products Soap Nuts Review

Green Virgin Products uses USDA certified organic soap nuts from the Sapindus Mukorossi tree, which is supposed to be the best species. The soap nuts are harvested, dried, hand sorted, and cleaned in Nepal before being packaged in a resealable, biodegradable bag and shipped to GVP in the United States.

GVP sent me a large bag of the whole nut/berries as well as a bottle of the liquid soap, which they extract and bottle themselves. For the liquid formula, they extract the saponin from the nuts using only water. Because the extract is from a fruit, the shelf life is very short (about 2 weeks), so they do have to use some preservatives to extend the shelf life. The 2 preservatives they use are rated a 0 and a 1 on the Skin Deep Database, which is just about as non-toxic as you can get.

I’ve been using both the whole berries and the liquid soap for about 2 months now, and I’m definitely a believer in the cleaning power of soap nuts! They both clean very well and leave our clothes feeling soft and smelling fresh. I really like the whole berries, but I do find myself reaching for the liquid soap over the whole berries for a few reasons:

  • Convenience: I love that I can just squirt the soap right into the washer – their pump bottle is so convenient and mess-free! 
  • Ease of use: Although they’re both easy to use, I find that the liquid is a little easier because all I have to do is add a few squirts into the wash water, and I’m done. With the whole berries, on the other hand, I have to remember to remove the muslin bag before putting the clothes in the dryer. Not a big deal, but it’s definitely an extra step to remember to fish it out.
  • Cold water: I wash most of our laundry in cold water, unless it’s a super-funky load of towels or something. You’re supposed to use warm or hot water with soap nuts, and I’ve found that the liquid soap works better than the whole berries in cold water washes. The fix for this: soak the bag of soap nuts in a cup of warm or hot water while your washer fills, then add it along with the clothes and wash as usual.

Green Virgin Products also carries bar soaps, a solid pre-treater bar, and moringa powder, as well as other cleaning products. The soaps are all handmade, non-toxic, and vegan. The pre-treater bar is really great, and I’ve gotten a lot of use out of it with all of the stains that come along with having 3 small children at home. It’s made with their exclusive cleaner concentrate and really does a pretty good job at pretreating stains. 

Looking for more ways to use soap nuts? Click here!

Be sure to follow Green Virgin Products for the latest sales and natural living tips:

Website | Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

Buy Green Virgin Products

You can purchase Green Virgin Products soap nuts right from their website or on Amazon. They have free US shipping for orders over $50, as well as a 90 day money-back guarantee! They usually ship out the same day or next day, and they try to use recycled boxes and newspapers as much as possible.

title: 10 Homemade Toothpaste Recipes

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Ready to make your own toothpaste? Yeah, I wasn’t either. Until I started reading more about the actual ingredients in conventional toothpastes. Now, I’m running for the hills and ready to try my hand at making a natural homemade toothpaste! 

We made the switch to natural store bought toothpaste a few years ago, and in the process, we’ve tried many different brands. Tom’s of Maine, JASON, Dessert Essence, to name a few. At the time, my main concern was the fluoride present in conventional toothpastes, so I was thankful to find a good variety of fluoride-free toothpastes to choose from. 

What’s wrong with conventional toothpaste?

One of the quickest ways to absorb something into your body is through the mouth. That’s why we need to be extra vigilant in making sure our toothpaste does not contain toxins which can then enter our bodies. In addition to fluoride, which has not been shown to actually reduce tooth decay, conventional toothpastes contain quite a few other ingredients that I now know should be avoided:

  • Sodium Lauryl Sulfate (SLS) – A foaming agent that can be found in everything from toothpaste to dish soap to shampoo. SLS has been linked to skin irritation, organ toxicity, and neurotoxicity.  Also known as sodium laureth sulfate (SLES) or ammonium lauryl sulfate (ALS). 
  • Glycerin – This is added to toothpaste (even the “natural” kinds) to give it that “pasty” consistency, but there’s speculation that glycerin tends to coat the teeth and prevent remineralization. The evidence behind this theory is not very clear, but I tend to err on the side of caution. 
  • Triclosan – An anti-microbial and anti-fungal agent added to soaps and detergents, and one brand of toothpaste (which also happens to be the brand I used before making the switch). It’s effectiveness remains controversial, and it’s been linked to everything from cancers to endocrine disruption to neurological damage in fetuses.
  • Other ingredients – Artificial colors, flavors, and sweeteners like aspartame and saccharin.

Homemade Toothpaste Recipes

Now that we know what’s in conventional, and even some natural, toothpastes, making homemade toothpaste doesn’t seem so crazy, does it? 

  1. Homemade Toothpaste from Pistachio Project – Two super simple recipes: one with equal parts coconut oil and baking soda, and one with just coconut oil and stevia.
  2. All-Natural Toothpaste from Crunchy Farm Baby – Bentonite clay, baking soda, coconut oil, and salt.
  3. Hippy Toothpaste from The Hippy Homemaker – Simple recipe with coconut oil, baking soda, and xylitol.
  4. Homemade Calcium Toothpaste from An Ordinary Housewife – A basic recipe that also adds calcium powder to help build up calcium.
  5. Homemade Toothpaste from Thank Your Body – Coconut oil, bentonite clay, and sea salt.
  6. Homemade No-Fluoride Toothpaste from Small Footprint Family – Baking soda, sea salt, and xylitol in a coconut oil base.
  7. Tooth soap and Tooth powder from Mommypotamus – A tooth soap recipe using Dr. Bronner’s soap, and a weekly tooth scrub to brighten teeth and prevent stains from building up.
  8. Homemade Toothpaste Like Earthpaste  from Don’t Waste the Crumbs – Learn how to make toothpaste that tastes just like Earthpaste for less than half the cost
  9. Homemade Kid’s Toothpaste from Live Simply – A kid friendly version with less bentonite clay and baking soda. She even uses a cute little squeeze tube to store it in for the kids.
  10. Homemade Remineralizing Toothpaste from Food Renegade – This recipe uses trace minerals to help re-build enamel and maintain healthy teeth and gums.

BONUS

Whitening & Remineralizing Toothpaste from Salam Mama – This is probably the most interesting homemade toothpaste recipe I’ve come across. In addition to the usual suspects like coconut oil and bentonite clay, this one also has activated charcoal, turmeric powder, and the option of flavoring it with organic spices like cinnamon, cloves, and ginger – yum!

Natural Toothpaste Alternatives from Living the Nourished Life – This is a great list of simple, one-ingredient methods for brushing your teeth. These are great if you’re need a quick freshening up and don’t have time to whip up a batch of homemade toothpaste. 

Alternative Store-Bought Toothpastes

Don’t have the time or desire to DIY your toothpaste? Not to worry, there are still several natural store-bought brands that are perfectly safe to use! My current favorite is Redmond’s Earthpaste made with clay, xylitol, essential oils, and salt. For more suggestions, check out the links below:

  • Crunchy Cheats: Toothpaste – Pistachio Project
  • Natural Toothpaste and Cleaning Recipes – Hybrid Rasta Mama

Further Reading

Toothbrushing is just one part of the equation to maintaining healthy teeth and gums; a healthy diet and nutrition is the other piece that we’re often never told about. I’ve just started reading Cure Tooth Decay by Ramiel Nagel, and it’s pretty fascinating stuff! Did you know we can not only prevent cavities, but also heal them naturally through proper nutrition? That’s news to me!

What do you and your family use to brush your teeth (homemade or otherwise)?

title: 7 Ways to Use Cashew Milk

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
This is a sponsored conversation written by me on behalf of Silk. The opinions and text are all mine.

In the world of non-dairy, nut-based milks, almond is king. But there’s a new kid on the block! Cashew milk is creamier, sweeter, and much more versatile than almond milk. Silk just released their new Creamy Cashew milk in Canada, and I’ve set out to learn more about its health benefits and find different ways to use cashew milk.

Cashews are one of my favorite nuts, so cashew milk just sounds perfect. Silk’s Creamy Cashew milk is so rich and creamy, unlike any other non-dairy milk I’ve tried.

Cashew Milk Nutrition

Cashews are really a wonderfully nutritious nut!

  • They’re high in B-vitamins
  • They’re chock full of minerals like copper, magnesium, iron, zinc, potassium, and calcium.
  • Cashews are high in monounsaturated fatty acids, mostly oleic acid, like the ones found in olive oil.
  • Silk’s Creamy Cashew milk is also cholesterol free and has as much calcium as dairy milk, with only 60 calories per serving and 33% less calories than skim milk.
  • It’s also a great source of vitamin D!

Silk’s Creamy Cashew milk, as well as their almond milk, does NOT contain carrageenan – a possible carcinogen. In fact, from what I’ve heard, Silk will be working on removing carrageenan from all of their milks! Also, all of Silk’s products are now Non-GMO Project Verified – yay! 🙂

How to Use Cashew Milk

Cashew milk is the creamiest of the non-dairy milks I’ve tried. Unlike most other nut milks, there is no “pulp” to strain out after the cashews are blended with water, so you’re getting the whole nut with all of its creamy deliciousness! And that creaminess really comes in handy when you’re looking for a non-dairy milk to use in your creamier recipes. Here are some simple ways to use cashew milk:

  1. Coffee/Tea – Add it to your coffee and tea for a great dairy-free creamer.
  2. Homemade Ice Cream – The creamy goodness of cashews really shines in this homemade ice cream recipe!
  3. Mashed Potatoes – Swap out the cream with cashew milk for some dairy-free mashed potatoes.
  4. Soups – Add it to soups to give them a thick, creamy texture.
  5. Cereal – Pour it over your cereal, granola, or oatmeal.
  6. Smoothies – Use it as the liquid base in your green smoothies.
  7. Salad Dressing – Add a splash to your salad dressing for a creamy effect.

Are you a fan of cashew milk? Be sure to share the love on Silk Canada’s Facebook page!

What’s your favorite nut-based milk, and how do you use it? Have you tried cashew milk yet?

title: September Ecocentric Mom Box Review

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
My September Ecocentric Mom Box is here! If you don’t know about Ecocentric Mom, it’s a fun and smart way to discover healthy, natural and organic products exclusively for moms, moms-to-be, and baby, delivered every-other-month right to your doorstep. 

So every couple months you get a box in the mail, like the one pictured above, with a bunch of new healthy, organic products to try. The boxes usually also include coupons or gift cards for the products – for $24 per box (including FREE shipping to the US) that’s a pretty awesome deal!

So far, I’ve reviewed the Mom & Baby box, as well as a Mom-to-Be box; but I gave birth to baby #3 last month, so this time I’m reviewing a Mom box – just for me. 🙂 No matter what season of mommyhood you’re in, there’s something for you.

September Ecocentric Mom Box Review

Here’s what was in my September Ecocentric Mom to Be box this month:

  1. Bioray After the Flow Herbal Supplement ($58 value – 4oz): Nourishes and strengthens the blood and body after the menstrual cycle. May help regulate ovulation when used regularly. This could be useful down the line when I get my cycle back, as I’ve always been a bit anemic. Just a couple droppers full added to your water, juice, or tea.
    *Use code: ecocentricmom for $10 off at http://bioray.com until Dec. 31st.
  2. WooBamboo Slim Handle Bamboo Toothbrush ($4.95 value): Soft bristle toothbrush made with eco-friendly bamboo.  They’re dentist approved, organic, nontoxic, and BPA-free. The brush handle is biodegradable, and the packaging uses recycled materials. A really great brush overall, and I love the soft bristles. The bamboo handle feels great in my hand, as opposed to my old plastic brush. I’m ordering a set for the whole family!
    *Use code: ECOCENTRIC for 20% off at http://ecmom.co/woobamboo until Dec. 31st.
  3. Annie’s Organic Cheddar Snack Mix Bunnies ($4.29 for 5oz; $1.19 for 1oz included): A crunchy combination of bunny shaped pretzels and crackers seasoned with organic cheddar cheese. We love Annie’s snacks around here, so these were not surprisingly delicious. The kids gobbled them up in no time. 🙂 I love that they’re certified organic and don’t contain any artificial flavors, colors, or preservatives. 
    *Includes $0.50 retail coupon.
  4. Jillian Wright “Breakout Blocker” Serum ($75 for 29ml; $7 for 3ml included): A non-irritating, non-drying clarifying serum to help control bacteria and brighten skin without harmful medicated ingredients. Helps reduce redness and fight acne on inflamed, oily, or problematic skin. Contains probiotics, Chinese herbs, and green tea. 
    *Ecocentric Moms received a special coupon for 20% off.
  5. PureProC Silk Smoothing Gel/Hydrating Serum (Smoothing Gel 15ml – $85; Hydrating Serum 30 ml – $60; 3ml samples included): Skincare products made with pure silk protein for skin health and anti-aging benefits without harsh chemicals or preservatives. Made in the USA, not tested on animals, and they’re paraben-, phthalate-, and toxin-free.
    *Use code: ECOMOM for 40% off at http://ecmom.co/PureProC until Oct. 31st.
  6. BioTerra “Z-Z-Z” Sleep Herbs ($19.99 for 60 capsules; $4.99 for 10 capsules included): Herbal supplement which helps relieve occasional sleeplessness and promote a restful sleep. Suggested dose is 2 capsules about 30 minutes before bedtime. Because I’m nursing, I haven’t been able to try these; so I’ll probably give them to my mom who sometimes has sleep issues. They’re non-GMO Project Verified, naturally gluten free, and vegan. And they’re coming to Walmart and Walgreens this Fall 2014!
    *Use code: ECOCENTRICMOM for 15% off at http://ecmom.co/bioterraherbs until Nov. 20th.
  7. 7th Heaven Natural Skin Masks ($2.99 value – 0.59oz): Healing, cleansing, revitalizing skin masks made from the finest clays, sourced from the Atlas Mountains of Africa to the sandy beaches of Thailand. These masks are truly 100% natural  – the White Thai Mud mask I received is made with lemongrass, lotus blossom, ginger, sesame, jasmine tea, and aloe vera. The mask is so relaxing and smells amazing!
    *Use code: ECOMOM2 for 20% off at http://ecmom.co/7thHeavenNaturals until Dec. 31st.
  8. eco-ditty Reusable Sandwich/Lunch Bags ($13.99): A reusable sandwich bag for a zero-waste lunch. Made in the USA from 100% organic cotton. They have a wide range of beautiful prints in sandwich and snack size, as well as a larger lunch bag. I’ve used reusable sandwich bags before that were lined with plastic on the inside; but these eco-ditty bags are all cotton inside and out. No synthetics, plastics, or chemicals ever touch your food. And they can be washed by hand, in the washing machine, or even the dishwasher.
    *Use code: ECOCENTRIC for 20% off at http://ecmom.co/ecodittylunch until Nov. 15th.
  9. Arora Creations “Bhindi Masala” Spice Blend ($3.99 value): This organic Indian spice blend smells amazing and is great for cooking sensitive greens like asparagus, okra, or string beans. Indian food is one of our favorites so I can’t wait to try this blend. It’s made from sea salt and certified organic amchur powder, cumin, coriander, turmeric, and chilies. I had to look up the amchur powder – it’s made from dried unripe green mangoes and has a honey-like fragrance and sour fruity flavor. Sounds delicious!

This was a very generous box this month, and probably my favorite one yet! Just the herbal supplement alone is worth more than double the cost of the box itself.  My favorite items this month were the WooBamboo toothbrush, the 7th Heaven skin mask, and the eco-ditty reusable sandwich bag.

The total value of this month’s box was well over $90. The  Ecocentric Mom box costs $24, which makes it an awesome deal!

You can connect with Ecocentric Mom on Facebook, Twitter, and Pinterest.

title: Green Smoothie Freezer Packs + Recipe Ideas

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Green smoothies are my favorite way to start the day, but I’ve been slacking lately because of lack time. To make things easier, I’ve been doing my smoothie prep work all at once with these green smoothie freezer packs. That way, making a nutritious green smoothie every morning is as easy as dumping a freezer pack into the blender and flipping a switch!

Green smoothies are all the rage now since they’re a great way to get a good serving of fruits and vegetables any time of day. It just gets tiring having to pull out several different bags and containers from the fridge and freezer, washing the fruit, then cutting it up, etc. There had to be a better way – and I found it at Live Simply!

How to Make Green Smoothie Freezer Packs

It’s super easy – gather your ingredients, wash and cut them up, then fill up your labeled bags using your favorite recipe! (Recipe ideas at the end of this post.)

Set Up

I get everything prepped and into separate bowls just so it’s easy to grab what I need. Then, it’s as simple as measuring out the different ingredients and adding them to the freezer bag.

I also add a banana to each smoothie pack because they’re naturally very sweet and creamy, and they add some bulk to the smoothie. Pro tip: Whenever I have some bananas at the bottom of the fruit bowl that are too soft and brown to eat on their own, I just peel them and throw them into a freezer bag and save them for smoothies.

 

Fill Your Bags

I measure out the fruit first and add it to the bag, then I top it off with my greens. The reason for this order is two-fold: 1) when you flip the bag into the blender, the greens are on the bottom and get blended with the liquid base first. 2) If you don’t have a high-speed blender, you can just pull out the greens first and blend them with the liquid base, then add the fruits gradually, blending until smooth.

For the greens, I usually use spinach, kale, or a combination of the two, but you can get adventurous and use other greens like bok choy, dandelion greens, romaine, or swiss chard. Pro tip: When measuring your greens, make sure to tightly pack them into your measuring cup.

Note: You will not be adding your liquid base to the freezer bags. When you’re ready to make your smoothie, you’ll just add the liquid to the bottom of the blender, then top it off with your green smoothie freezer pack.

 

Label and Freeze Bags

Once you’ve got your bags filled, label them with what’s inside and date them. If you prefer, you can also add notes about how much (and what kind of) liquid base you’ll need to add to the blender. I don’t bother with that because I just choose it on the fly, depending on what I have on hand or what I feel like drinking that morning.

How to Build a Green Smoothie

Building your green smoothie is actually quite easy if you just follow a simple formula. Personally, I stick to the super simple formula from Simple Green Smoothies which, for 2 servings (16 oz each) is:

  • 2 cups leafy greens
  • 2 cups liquid base
  • 2-3 cups fruit

Superfoods & Boosters

To add even more nutritional value to your already healthy green smoothie, try adding 1-2 tablespoons of these boosters and superfoods to the blender when you’re ready to make your smoothie (ie: Don’t add them to the freezer pack). These are great sources of proteins and healthy fats to help make for a more well-rounded smoothie.

  • hemp seeds
  • chia seeds
  • almond butter (store-bought or make your own)
  • protein powder
  • flax seeds
  • greek yogurt (probiotics)
  • lemon juice (immune -boosting and helps the body absorb the iron in leafy greens)

Green Smoothie Freezer Pack Recipes

Green Smoothie Freezer Packs
2014-08-17 07:23:10
Make morning smoothie prep a breeze with these pre-packed green smoothie freezer packs!
Write a review
Save Recipe
Print
Ingredients
  1. 2 cups leafy greens (spinach, kale, bok choy, dandelion, romaine, swiss chard)
  2. 2 cups liquid (water, milk, coconut water, almond milk, juice)
  3. 3 cups fruit (replace 1 cup with a frozen banana or 1/2 avocado for creaminess)
  4. optional superfoods or boosters
Instructions
  1. Add fruits and greens to labeled freezer bags.
  2. On smoothie day, add liquid base to blender, then add smoothie pack contents, and blend until smooth.
  3. Add optional superfoods or boosters, and blend again.
Notes
  1. If you don't have a high speed blender, try blending the greens with the liquid base first, then adding the fruit.

 Here are recipes for some of the bags in the photos above:

Strawberry Mango Green Smoothie

Strawberry Mango Smoothie

  • 2 cups greens
  • 1 cup strawberries
  • 1 cup bananas
  • 1 cup water + 1 cup orange juice

Peach Strawberry Green Smoothie

  • 2 cups greens
  • 1 cup strawberries
  • 1 cup peaches
  • 1 banana
  • 2 cups almond milk

Strawberry Banana Green Smoothie

  • 2 cups greens
  • 2 cups strawberries
  • 1 banana
  • 1 cup milk + 1 cup water

Mixed Berry Green Smoothie

  • 2 cups greens
  • 3 cups mixed berries
  • 2 cups water

title: Tea Time With Earth Mama Angel Baby Teas

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Disclosure: This post was written as part of a paid brand ambassadorship for Earth Mama Angel Baby. All opinions are 100% my own. This post also contains affiliate links because I truly love Earth Mama’s products and support their mission!

As I’m nearing the end of my pregnancy, I’ve fallen into a nighttime routine of sipping a cup of hot tea and catching up on some work. It’s the most peaceful part of my day after all the craziness that comes along with being pregnant and caring for two kids under 4. 🙂

It’s the third and final week of my Earth Mama Angel Baby Challenge, and this week was all about the their natural, organic comforting teas! Earth Mama Angel Baby teas are great for pregnancy, postpartum, breastfeeding, and beyond. This week I’ve been trying out the Morning Wellness Tea and the Heartburn Tea. (If you’re in Canada, like I am, these are called Mama’s Morning Tea and Mama’s Tummy Tea).

I’m no stranger to a cup of hot tea, as is the norm for anyone with Middle Eastern roots, but herbal tea is an area that I’ve just recently started dabbling in. If you’re new to herbal teas, the line from Earth Mama Angel Baby is a great place to start. They’re certified organic, non-GMO, gluten-free, and naturally caffeine free. They also taste absolutely delicious!

Earth Mama Angel Baby Organic Teas

The Morning Wellness Tea (Mama’s Morning Tea) is meant to ease morning sickness, but can be enjoyed whether or not you’re pregnant. With ginger, spearmint, chamomile, and a twist of orange peel, this tea is great for easing nausea, queasiness, upset stomach, or travel tummy, so it’s good for the whole family. The flavors blend so perfectly, and it tastes wonderful – even my 3 year old liked it!

The Heartburn Tea (Mama’s Tummy Tea) was made specifically for tackling heartburn in pregnancy, but of course can be used by anyone to help put out the fire. Made with marshmallow root, lemon balm, chamomile, spearmint, and red raspberry leaf, this tea is the perfect after-dinner soothing drink to help keep that nasty heartburn at bay. Apparently, this tea is also good for treating sore throat, scratchy cough, and diarrhea, though I haven’t had to use it for any of these yet. I love this tea so much, it’s become the star of my nightly tea-time routine!

Aside from the lovely taste and soothing herbs in these teas, my favorite part of Earth Mama Angel Baby teas is that they come in biodegradable tea bags, and the cartons are 100% recycled and recyclable – yay!

Check out Earth Mama Angel Baby at their website and connect with them on Facebook,Twitter, Pinterest, and Google+ for the latest on sales and exclusive offers!

Earth Mama Angel Baby products can be purchased through their website, on Amazon, or locally at a store near you.

Do you have a tea time ritual? What is your favorite herbal tea to help you relax after a long day?

title: July Ecocentric Mom to Be Box Review

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
My July Ecocentric Mom to be Box is here! If you don’t know about Ecocentric Mom, it’s a fun and smart way to discover healthy, natural and organic products exclusively for moms, moms-to-be, and baby, delivered every-other-month right to your doorstep. 

So every couple months you get a box in the mail, like the one pictured above, with a bunch of new healthy, organic products to try. The boxes usually also include coupons or gift cards for the products – for $24 per box (including FREE shipping to the US) that’s a pretty awesome deal!

Since I’m nearing the end of my pregnancy, I’m now reviewing the Mom-to-Be box, but they also have boxes for “mom” and “mom and baby”, so no matter what season of mommyhood you’re in, there’s something for you.

July Ecocentric Mom to Be Box Review

Here’s what was in my July Ecocentric Mom to Be box this month:

  1. AROMAGLAGE Botanical Fragrance & Insect Repellent ($30 for 8ml; 1ml included): Natural, insect repellent that also smells very nice thanks to the vanilla, citrus, and cedar wood. Contains no synthetic fragrances, parabens, or SLS. 
  2. Cream Foundation from Lauren Brooke Cosmetiques ($27 full size; 3 travel sizes included): A lightweight, all-natural foundation that’s very smooth and has an SPF of 28! I’m not much of a makeup person, but this definitely looks like something I would wear if the occasion arises. 
  3. Sample Personalized Cards and Stationary from eInvite ($0.96 per card; 5 included): These cards are made in the USA, and seem to be of very quality. Their baby line includes shower invitations, birth announcements, nursery decor, and more. Also includes a 20% off discount code.
  4. Lip Balm from Savannah Red ($2.99 value): Natural, vegan lip balm that smells amazing! Goes on smooth and leaves lips very soft. They carry a wide variety of fun flavors, like coconut, peach, watermelon, apple, and cinnamon. They’re very affordable too! Also includes 20% off discount code.
  5. Spices and Tea from The Natural Suburban ($7 for 6oz spice, $9.50 for 20oz tea; samples included): A savory herb spice mix, and an herbal sunshine tea. Both smell wonderful. Also includes a 20% off discount code.
  6. Belly Balm by Bears Beauty ($12 for 1oz; travel size included): All-natural, vegan cream for pregnant bellies. Goes on a little greasy at first, but once it’s rubbed in well, it’s fine. Smells nice and doesn’t leave a residue. All their products are made with organic hemp seed oil. Also includes a 15% off discount code.
  7. YogaVive Apple Chips ($4.49 value): Apple chips made from certified organic Fuji apples. They’re baked, then popped for an interesting, unique snack. I had the chocolate variety which was still good, but I think I’d prefer a plain apple flavor instead. 
  8. Water Wipes All-Natural Baby Wipes ($0.99 for 10-pk travel size): Probably the most natural, chemical-free baby wipes I’ve ever seen. They just contain water (99.9%) and some grapefruit seed extract to preserve them. They’re available at most major retailers like Walgreens, and online at Diapers.com. Also includes discount code.
  9. Happy Baby Meal Time ($9.95 value): A short, small board book for baby that talks about different parts/foods for meal time. My 1 year old loved the bright colors and thick pages. 
  10. Bathing Baby Hair & Body Wash by Bathtime Baby ($7.50 value): A gentle hair and body wash for babies that’s free of parabens, sulfates, artificial fragrances, and dyes. It’s hypoallergenic, cruelty-free, vegan, and scented only with essential oils and plant extracts. I loved the mild calendula scent and my son’ sensitive skin loved the gentle formula. They also carry many other baby products like lotion, diaper cream, massage oil, and baby powder, as well as a line of kids products. Also includes a 20% off discount code.
  11. Miscellaneous Coupons

Mom’s Stuff

title: Natural Mama Care From Earth Mama Angel Baby

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Disclosure: This post was written as part of a paid brand ambassadorship for Earth Mama Angel Baby. All opinions are 100% my own. This post also contains affiliate links because I truly love Earth Mama’s products and support their mission!

It’s Week 2 of my Earth Mama Angel Baby challenge, and I’m so excited about the two products I’ve been testing out in many different ways! Remember, Earth Mama Angel Baby products are some of the most versatile products on the market. So if you don’t finish a product for its intended purpose, there are most likely a whole bunch of other wonderful uses for it!

Natural Mama Care from Earth Mama Angel Baby

This week I’ve been using the New Mama Bottom Spray and the Natural Nipple Butter, and can’t believe how many “off the box” uses exist for just these two products.

Natural Nipple Butter

The Natural Nipple Butter is Earth Mama Angel Baby’s star product, not only because of how well it works but also because it’s the only organic, non-GMO Project verified nipple cream on the market. Most nipple creams contain lanolin, which is actually not as safe as we think, so Earth Mama Angel Baby set out to make a lanolin-free nipple cream that works wonders. I still have a few weeks before I’ll be breastfeeding again, so I’m definitely looking forward to using this for its intended purpose.

For now, I’m loving all of these other wonderful uses for this amazing cream:

Chapped Lips – Goes on smooth, and leaves lips feeling silky soft!

Dry Skin & Cuticles – Use it on dry, cracked skin on elbows, knees, ankles, and even during a mani/pedi on your cuticles.

Scrapes & Rashes – Keeps cuts and scrapes soft and protected to speed up healing. Works great on minor rashes on cheeks, nose, and tender skin.

New Mama Bottom Spray

The New Mama Bottom Spray, a soothing perineal spray for new mamas, is made to help heal and soothe the discomfort that comes with postpartum swelling and soreness, episiotomies, and hemorrhoids. Honestly, I can’t wait to use it for that purpose after baby #3 arrives in a few short weeks.

In the meantime, I’ve discovered a long list of other unconventional uses for this wonderful spray:

Facial Toner – So cool and refreshing for a morning pick-me-up!

Diaper Rash Spray – In a pinch, I’ve sprayed this on baby girl’s red, inflamed diaper rash – worked great!

Swelling and Puffiness – Use it for puffy eyes, swollen feet, and any other inflamed areas.

Sunburn – I sprayed it on my son’s shoulders when we were out in the sun for too long, and it immediately cooled him right down.

Bug Bites – After gardening, we’re always left with at least a couple of mosquito bites – a quick spray will usually take away the itch so we don’t scratch.

Check out Earth Mama Angel Baby at their website and connect with them on Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, and Google+ for the latest on sales and exclusive offers!

Earth Mama Angel Baby products can be purchased through their website, on Amazon, or locally at a store near you.

title: Pack an Eco-Friendly Lunch with PlanetBox (+ a Giveaway!)

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Welcome to the second annual Green Your School Year Giveaway Hop, hosted by Happy Mothering, Easy Green Mom and Brittleby’s Corner through the Green Moms Network! We’ve teamed up with a group of bloggers to bring you the chance to win prizes that will help you kick your child’s school year off on a green foot! After entering my giveaway, be sure to hop around and enter all of the other #GreenSchool giveaways listed on the linky at the bottom of this post for your chance to win more eco-friendly and healthy giveaways!

It’s Back to School time! Have your kids started the school year yet? Are you homeschooling? Do you pack a lunch for yourself to take to work everyday? If you answered ‘yes’ to any of these questions, you’re going to want to check out today’s tips for packing an eco-friendly lunch!

Whether it’s at work or school, the amount of waste generated everyday from lunch is unbelievable. We’ve become so accustomed to convenience packs, single-serve sizes, foil, plastic wrap, etc., and although these things make packing a lunch quick and easy, the environmental impact that they carry cannot be ignored. 

So what’s the solution? Pack an eco-friendly lunch, of course! Starting with the basics, the smallest changes we can make all involve ditching the single-use, disposable products for their reusable counterparts. Are you drinking from plastic water bottles or juice boxes? Invest in a reusable stainless steel or glass water bottle to carry your beverages. Instead of asking for plastic cutlery at the lunch counter, consider bringing your own silverware from home or buying a set of reusable utensils just for your lunchbox. Ditch the single-use napkins and paper towels, and treat yourself to a set of nice cloth napkins that can be washed and reused over and over again.

A few simple steps is all it takes to make a huge impact in the long run. Although our family usually brings our own lunch and snacks when we go out to the park or for a walk, the thing I’ve been really missing is a nice lunch box to carry it in. That’s why I was so excited when the friendly people at PlanetBox contacted me to review their eco-friendly lunch boxes!

PlanetBox Eco-Friendly Lunch Boxes

PlanetBox is the smart, eco-friendly lunch box that’s part bento box and part TV dinner tray. They’re made of high quality, food-safe stainless steel and independently certified to be free of lead, phthalates, PVC, PBA, and other toxic chemicals. The lunch boxes themselves are also 100% recyclable, meaning less waste in our landfills!

I received a PlanetBox Rover Complete to review. They carry three different sizes; the RoverBox is the middle size, but it has the most compartments. The Rover Complete Kit includes a Rover lunchbox, the Big and Little Dipper for wet messy foods, your choice of super fun magnets designs, as well as a Rover Carry Bag for easy transport available in a variety of vibrant colors.

Three sizes of lunch box

What I Love

After using my PlanetBox with my 3-year old son on our walks and park trips, there’s a lot that I’ve come to love about this neat little lunch box.

  • Compartments – Even though the Rover box is not the largest, it does have the most compartments. This is great for my son who is a total snacker and likes to have a variety of foods to munch on when we’re out.
  • Foods Don’t Touch – If you have a toddler, you’ll most likely understand why I love this. My son can’t stand for his foods to touch, so the divided compartments are really awesome in that sense. Nothing ever spills over to a different compartment.
  • Dippers – The big and little dippers (cute names, right?) are so handy – I totally recommend including them in your kit. They’re great for dipping sauces or yogurt and messier meals like rice and beans or spaghetti. They also have a great seal so no worries on them accidentally leaking in the box.
  • Size – I love how compact these boxes are, and yet they still hold a good amount of food. 
  • Durability – We haven’t really put our box through that much so far, but just the way the box is made I can tell it will last us a long time. The latch that closes the box is very sturdy and secure, and if you get the carry bag as well you’re good to go.
  • Carry Bag – The bag is optional, but I would absolutely recommend it. It not only keeps the lunch box padded and secure; it also has a nice amount of storage space as well. On the outside, I can fit my son’s 12 oz stainless steel water bottle, and there’s a large pocket that we use for our napkins or extra snacks. Inside there are straps for your utensils, as well as a large mesh area which is meant to hold the optional cold pack.
  • Easy Clean-Up – The PlanetBox is very easy to clean, and it’s dishwasher safe – even in the bottom rack! You just have to remember to remove the magnets first if you’re using them.

Some Things to Keep In Mind

There’s not much that I don’t love about the PlanetBox, although there are a few things that do need to be mentioned.

  • Price – The Rover Complete Kit that I reviewed sells for $59.95, so it’s not exactly inexpensive (The very smallest, basic box they carry is $34.95). However, it really is an investment in a quality lunch box that will last for years; not to mention how much it saves in disposable products, as well as the amount of waste it diverts from the landfills. 
  • Size – I really do love the compact size, but at just 1.5 inches tall, the Rover box could use a little bit of height to accommodate a thicker sandwich (like a bagel), or even a small muffin. The other two sizes (Launch and Shuttle) stand at 2 inches tall, so that may actually be better. Also, the sandwich compartment seems a little small – I usually have to cut a little off the ends to make it fit; but my son doesn’t like the crust so I’m usually cutting it off anyways.
  • Dippers – The dippers are so useful, but if you’re sending them to school with little ones they may have a hard time actually getting them open. My 3 year old can open the little dipper without a problem, but his little hands couldn’t grasp the big dipper enough to open it. Just something to keep in mind, as your child may need to ask for help from a teacher to open them at school.
  • Lay Flat – When the box is open, it lays completely flat, so it takes up double the space when you’re eating. I wish there was a way to keep the lid standing up. I’ve found that you could place it in the carry bag and kind of zip up the bag a little bit on each side so that the bag’s cover stands up; that way the lid on the lunch box could just lean against the bag’s cover. If the carry bag or the lunch box had a way of keeping the lid up when it’s open, that would be really helpful.

Final Thoughts on the PlanetBox

I absolutely love our PlanetBox lunch box! It makes packing a lunch for our days out so much easier, and dare I say even pleasurable? Even my son seems to be eating a wider variety of foods just because of the way they’re presented in the lunch box, so that’s a huge plus for me as he tends to be a very picky eater. The lunch box is very sturdy, and it seems like it will last us a very long time. Would I buy another one? Absolutely!

Connect with PlanetBox

You can purchase PlanetBox’s eco-friendly lunch boxes from their website or on Amazon. Be sure to connect with them at the links below for the latest on sales and special offers!

Website | Facebook | Twitter | Google+ | Pinterest | Instagram

Win a PlanetBox Eco-Friendly Lunch Box!

Guess what?! PlanetBox is also offering one lucky reader the chance to win a PlanetBox Rover Complete Kit of their own – that’s a $60 value! Just use the Rafflecopter form below to enter. Giveaway is open to US residents only. Ends August 19, 2014. Please see full terms and conditions below. Good luck!

a Rafflecopter giveaway
Be sure to enter the grand prize giveaway! One winner will receive an eco-friendly bookcase from Tidy Books; a Back to School outfit from KicKee Pants; a Waste Free Lunch Kit from Kids Konserve; $50 worth of YumEarth products; a $50 Gift Card to Swap.com and a $50 Gift Certificate to BuyGreen.com. Enter here.
